H0.text: Refraction is the characteristic of sound that makes it possible for bats to fly in the dark without hitting any objects.

H1.text: Reflection, the property of sound waves that bounce off surfaces, allows bats to fly in the dark without hitting any objects.

H2.text: Conduction is the characteristic of sound that allows bats to fly in the dark without hitting any objects.

H3.text: Amplification is the characteristic of sound that enables bats to fly in the dark without hitting any objects.

A4.text: The complex geometry of ridges on the inner surface of bat ears helps to sharply focus echolocation signals and to passively listen for any other sound produced by the prey.

A5.text: Bats can estimate the elevation of their target using the interference patterns from the echoes reflecting from the tragus, a flap of skin in the external ear.

A6.text: The time and loudness differences are used by the animals to perceive distance and direction.

A7.text: Using echolocation, bats can determine how far away an object is, the object's size, shape and density, and the direction (if any) that an object is moving.
